div.p: 1. V. Tuesday— From New-Brunswick to New-York— Steam-Boat President—

We embarked at six this morning in the Steamboat Thistle from New-Brunswick and landed at New-York at ten. There was rain during great part of the passage— At Perth-Amboy, Major Lamb came onboard the boat, and came to New-York— He has leased his house there to a Mr Crane, who keeps it as a Hotel. At New-York we came to the Washington Hotel newly fitted up—and kept by Hamilton, who heretofore kept the Exchange Hotel in Boston— We only stopp’d to dine; and found that John Kirke, with the Horses and Carriage was at the City
Hotel. At Hamilton’s I received several visitors; Oliver Wolcott, a man whose condition somewhat resembles my own— Having survived the age of active life, he has no fixed abode; but resides chiefly with his Children. He is nearly or quite four-score years of age; and until about three years past was Governor of Connecticut— They then quietly dropp’d him and elected Gideon Tomlinson in his place— Mr Wolcott appears to retain possession of his faculties, and was much disposed to conversation upon the prevailing politics of the time— But we were very soon interrupted, against my inclination, for I should have been glad to listen long to Mr Wolcott. He views the prospects of the Union, with great sagacity, and with hopes more sanguine than mine— He thinks the continuance of the Union will depend upon the heavy population of Pennsylvania; and that its gravitation will preserve the Union— He holds the South-Carolina turbulence, rather too much in contempt— The domineering Spirit, naturally springs from the institution of Slavery; and when as in South-Carolina, the Slaves are more numerous than their masters; the domineering Spirit, is wrought up to its highest pitch of intenseness— The South-Carolinians are attempting to govern the Union as they govern their Slaves, and there are too many indications that abetted as they are by all the Slave-driving interest of the Union, the free portion of the population will cower before them, and truckle to their insolence. This is my apprehension. Mr Wolcott considers their bullying only according to its own character, and supposes it will be harmless because it is impotent— Mr Johnson of Utica with his wife youngest daughter of my brother Charles, is upon an excursion to the South, for her health—which is suffering with rhumatism— His Son is a stout boy of thirteen, whom he says he proposes sending to Cambridge— Mr Vosberg paid me a visit of curiosity—an entire Stranger, who was disposed to give me biographical anecdotes of Martin Van Buren, the present Secretary of State: Vosberg says that he and Van-Buren were born in the same village— Their fathers next door neighbours, and that he has known him from childhood. The best thing that he had to tell of Martin, before he became a patriot was that on his father’s death, he relieved himself from responsibility for his debts by pleading the Statute of Limitations— The Teacher was a young man whose name he told me, but I did not retain it in Memory. Mr Le Ray told me that he should present his claim to Congress on account of his father’s services during the War of our Revolution, if a favourable opportunity should occur— He shewed me a recommendatory Letter from General La Fayette to me which he asked my permission to retain, and to use if necessary, to which I consented— He told me he had been totally ruined by the New-York Canals— His immense Estate in Lands being distant from the Canals, and having thereby sunk three fourths of their value— He lives now barely by the forbearance and kindness of his creditors. Mr Blunt came into Hamilton’s while we were at dinner— Told us Charles King and his wife were gone this day to Albany, to attend the wedding of Genl. Van Rensselaer’s daughter. Told me also that Alexander Hamilton’s papers were now in the hands of Francis Baylies, who is to write the biography— We embarked in the Steam-boat President Captain R. S. Bunker and at 4. P.M. left the wharf in the North-river near the Battery which the Rhode-Island Steam-boats now frequent. The weather was still overcast and gloomy. Wind East. The only fellow passengers whom I knew, were a Mr Johnson, and another whose name I did not recollect, both of Baltimore— Our navigation was rapid, but there was no favourable change in the weather— My wife deeply depressed in Spirits, and myself in a disposition, not more cheering or cheerful—
2. V. Wednesday.— Landed at Providence— Quincy.

We passed an uncomfortable night. Before three in the morning I was awakened, by the rolling of the Boat: we had passed out of the Sound at the East end of Long-Island— The wind still East—a heavy swell, and many of the Passengers Sea-sick— Mrs Adams quite ill— The child unwell, but not thoroughly Sea-sick— The fog so thick that for two hours or more we lay to every five or ten minutes to sound— The Benjamin Franklin pass’d in sight, about Sunrise, having passed the night at Newport— A thick fog, which dispersed as we were reaching that harbour— At nine we came to the wharf at Providence, just before which Mrs Adams had a faint turn— I hesitated whether we should not all stop for the day at Providence, but she recovered and urged me to proceed in the Stage; intending to come on herself in the Carriage as far as Walpole this Evening— I came with William—the black man in the Stage— It stopp’d for five minutes at Attleborough where I saw Coll. Hatch— We dined at Fuller’s in Walpole— At Dedham I quitted the Stage, in which I had as fellow passengers a Major Coffin, and a Mr Glover, both apparently Officers in the British Service, from Canada— From Dedham I came in an open Jersey Waggon with one horse; driven by Mr Gay to Quincy, where I arrived with William at five in the afternoon— I found in the house a woman, my Son Charles’s Cook, whom he had left here to receive us— My brother’s Son Joseph Harrod soon afterwards came in— I wrote a Letter to my Son Charles to be sent in to Boston, by the Milkman to-morrow morning.
3. V. Thursday.

My brother and his daughter, Abigail S. were here this morning. My Son Charles and his wife came out from Boston— I expected my family would have arrived here before dinner, and had again half a day of anxious expectation, and suspense— They arrived at six in the Evening having come this day the whole way from Providence. They landed there yesterday shortly after I came off in the Stage: and as I had advised they went to the Franklin house, to give the horses and take themselves a short repose. They were at the point of leaving the House to proceed to Walpole, when John’s child was suddenly seized with a fainting or convulsion fit— The alarm to my wife, was inexpressible—for a short time they thought the child dead— A warm bath recovered her, and they sent for Dr Mauran, who attended repeatedly in the course of the day. This accident was attributed to the effect of the violent motion of the Steamboat on the nervous system of the child. They remained over Night at Providence; and came from thence this morning. And thus Providence in judgment has yet remembered mercy. There is no other shelter from the storm— The child though still pale, appears to be quite recovered— My brother and his daughters were again here this Evening— My Son Charles and his wife returned to Boston— On arriving here yesterday I resumed my daily reading of three chapters of the Bible, at the 16th. Chapter of Matthew; and this morning I took up again the Orations of Cicero, and read his defence of Caius Rabirius, charged by the Tribune of the People Titus Labienus with the crime of Perduellion—a complication of murder and treason. Thirty-six years before, the factious tribune Saturninus had been killed in a popular tumult excited by himself. Quintus Labienus perished with him— His nephew Titus Labienus, being one of the Tribunes of the People, the year when Cicero was Consul, brought this accusation against
Rabirius for having killed Saturninus— It was one of Julius Caesar’s intrigues, to put down the Senatorial party— The cause was first tried by Duumvirs, drawn by lot, and Caesar was one of them— They condemned Rabirius, who appealed to the People. The defence of Cicero was delivered before them, but Labienus had limited the time allowed Cicero for speaking to half an hour. Part even of the Oration delivered in that time is lost. The finest passage of it is the turn which the Orator gave to a shout of the multitude to silence him upon his declaring his regret that he could not admit that Saturninus had fallen by the hand of Rabirius— He says he is happy to hear the shout because it shewed how small a portion of his hearers concurred in it—and that the Roman People would hardly have made him their Consul, if he could have been intimidated by so feeble a clamour as that— A second shout he remarks was weaker than the first, and he advises the clamourers to be silent, and withhold the proof of their folly and of their scarcity— It seems there was yet so much danger for Rabirius, that the Praetor Metellus Celer, took down the standard on the Janiculum, which de facto dissolved the Meeting of the People, and Rabirius thus escaped condemnation.
4. V. Friday.

My brother was here this morning, and I received visits from Mr Peter Whitney, and Mr John Marston. Mrs Pitts, and Mrs Kirke with her child arrived: having come round in a coasting vessel from Alexandria where they embarked on the 21st. of last Month— This completes the portion of our family who have effected this Northern Emigration for the Summer— To most families in this Country, this removal would scarcely be more difficult than it would individually to me— I find it of oppressive magnitude, and distressing charge— Afternoon walk— Call at J. Greenleaf’s. His daughter Lucy wife of George Dawes—with four Children, and Mary, wife of Henry Dawes, with one Child there. Called afterwards at my brother’s. I read this morning the first Oration against Catiline: it is short, and I think I had translated it forty years ago. But I find in Ernesti’s Edition of Cicero, before the Orations against Rullus, the fragments of the two Orations for Caïus Cornelius, and of one in Toga candida against his competitors for the Consulship, Caïus Antonius and Catiline. These fragments are principally preserved by Asconius Pedianus— The two Orations for Cornelius are mentioned as among the greatest of his efforts, and he cites passages from them in his Orator ch. 67. and 70. I read these fragments but find nothing in them very remarkable— My progress here will be much more slow, with the same devotion of Time than it was at Washington. There I had nothing but the text of Cicero, in the pocket volumes of the Regent’s Classics— What I did not understand, I was obliged to pass over— Here I have many Editions of Cicero. Translations French and English. Prevost’s translation of Middleton’s life of the Orator, Dictionaries Commentators, Histories of Rome; and Dissertations upon Roman Manners, Government and Institutions— It is the race of the dog and the tortoise— Great part of this morning was absorbed in looking up the works that I possess relating to Cicero— The first is an Edition in nine Quarto Volumes, of Joseph d’Olivet, ad usum Delphini, printed by John Manfré at Padua 1753— The principal merit of this work is the large type in which it is printed. The Indexes in the ninth Volume are useful, and it contains the Historia Ciceronis in annals by Francis Fabricius, perhaps the model of Middleton— 2. The second Edition of John Augustus Ernesti—6 Volumes Octavo—printed at Halle 1757. The second Volume containing the Orations is divided into two volumes, and the last volume is the Clavis, worth more for
the illustration of Cicero, than all the other Commentaries upon Cicero ever written. It is in five Indexes 1. of Laws. 2. Geographical 3. Historical 4. Latinity. 5 Graeco-Latin— The Regent’s Edition, omits from the Clavis the Index of Latinity. 3. The Edition by Sallemand. 14. Volumes duodecimo. of the Barbour collection—merely the text; with Ernesti’s Arguments: very convenient for reading. 4. Wells and Lilly’s Boston Edition 12. Volumes duodecimo. I left at Washington. 5. The Edition of Dionysius Gothofredus. one Volume Quarto, printed at Geneva, by Peter and James Chouet 1632. with marginal Notes— 6. Schrevelius— Elzevir Edition. one Volume Quarto 1661. Two copies— This has also the Historia Ciceronis of Francis Fabricius.
5. V. Saturday.

My brother was here, and brought two or three Newspapers— I received an invitation to attend the Anniversary dinner of the Antient and Honourable Artillery Company next Monday— The Card enclosed by Lieutt. Coll. Quincy, to whom I addressed an answer with my excuses— Kirke went into Boston, and brought out the Phaëton with the one healthy horse— The other having been diseased with the glanders and expected to die— Mr Baxter brought out also all the baggage we had sent round by Water. I had a Letter from Mr S. L. Southard, written on the Evening of the day we saw him at Trenton, and giving the information which he had obtained of Kirke’s going from Trenton for New-York last Saturday— I wrote in reply to this Letter, but did not finish mine— A Letter also from Mr Benjamin Vaughan of Hallowell, enclosing some newspaper notices of the late William Tudor— Mrs Adams bound up this afternoon, some rasberry vines in the garden— Charles’s Cook left us. I read the second Oration against Catiline, and further collected my Ciceronian books— Besides the several Editions of all his works, excepting the newly discovered books de Republica, noted yesterday, I have John George Graevius’s Edition of the familiar Epistles, 2. Volumes Octavo— Elzevir’s 1677— 3. Volumes duodecimo—select Orations, with a French Translation of Villefore, revised by Wailly— a fourth Volume, containing in Latin and French four Philippics of Demosthenes and the four Orations against Catiline; by the Abbé d’Olivet— De Natura deorum 2. Volumes with translation of d’Olivet— The Tusculans 3 Volumes duodecimo— Bouhier and d’Olivet— An old French translation of the familiar Epistles 1687. 2. Vols. duodecimo. The same with translation of the Abbe Prevost 1745 two of three Volumes—Friendship, Old Age—the dream of Scipio and the political Letter to Quintus in one Volume, with Translation of De Barrett: the 12th. Volume of the complete translation of Du Ryer—the 4th. Volume of the Epistles to Atticus with the translation and notes of the Abbé Mongault— These mutilated sets are by losses of books at the Athenaeum— The Abbe Prevost’s translation of Middleton’s life of Cicero— Duncan’s English translation of select Orations 1. Volume Octavo— Melmoth’s translation of the familiar Epistles 3. Volumes Octavo— The History of Fabricius—and Schottus de Nodis Ciceronis— I have yet other books containing comments and illustrations of Cicero—as Fabricius, Bibliotheca Latina— Justus Lipsius, Gronovius and others.
6. V. Sunday.

My wife was seized just before two O’Clock this Morning with an extremely violent Chill, and excruciating cramps which continued all the remainder of the Night, and followed by a burning fever— Soon after day-light I sent for Dr Holbrook, who came soon after six, and found her still in agonies of pain; which bleeding partially relieved.
Heard Mr Whitney in the forenoon, from 2. Corinthians 1.3.4. [“]Blessed be God, even the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies, and the God of all comfort: 4. Who comforteth us in all our tribulations.” a text well suited to the condition of my mind. The communion was administered after the usual service. A heavy rain prevented my attendance in the afternoon— General Dearborn and Mr Degrand took tea here— Dearborn who was removed from the Office of Collector at Boston is now a member of the Senate from the County of Norfolk in the State Legislature— They are now in Session, but will adjourn to-morrow, or the next day— The first Session of the 21st. Congress, was closed last Monday. Of the four Bills of internal improvement, which passed both houses of Congress on Saturday the President approved only one; and with that he sent a Message announcing that he signed it with the Understanding that it should receive a particular Construction— As it was an Appropriation for a road, the construction of the Laws will depend entirely upon himself but this explanatory Message, qualifying the signature of the President to an Act of Congress, is unexampled in this Country, and contrary to the Spirit of the Constitution—a Usurpation of the judiciary power, and susceptible of great abuse as a precedent— The Appropriation for the Road from Washington to Frederick he returned to the Senate with his objections, and the subsequent vote upon it there was 22 for and 16 against it. His negative thus controuls decided majorities in both houses of Congress— He defeated the appropriation for the continuation of the Cumberland Road, and the Bill authorizing the erection of several new Light-house, and directing many new surveys, in a different manner. When the joint Committee of the two Houses went to inform him that they were ready to adjourn, and to enquire if he had any further communication to make to them; he said he had nothing further, except that he retained those two Bills for further consideration. The provision of the Constitution is that a Bill presented to him shall become a Law, without his signature, if not returned by him within ten days, Sundays excepted; unless the Congress by their adjournment prevent its return. His remark to the Committee doubtless was to give warning that Congress by their adjournment would prevent his returning those Bills— These are remarkable Events as bringing into operation Constitutional principles— The Presidential veto has hitherto been exercised with great reserve. Not more than four or five acts of Congress have been thus arrested by six Presidents and in forty years— He has rejected four in three days. The overseer ascendency is complete.
7. V:30. Monday.

This was the day of the Artillery Election; a sort of traditionary Holiday not only in, but for many miles round Boston— My workman in the Garden, Augustus Farrar, asked and obtained leave of absence for the day: and Josiah Adams junr. postponed work till to-morrow— The last time I was in the State on the day of the Artillery Election was in 1809. when they handled me roughly in their toasts— They now invited me to their feast— Had the weather been ever so fine, I could have taken no pleasure in it—but the day was showery. Dr Holbrook was here, a second time last Evening, and again this Morning— My wife has continued extremely ill, with a high fever, and violent inflammation, chiefly on the right side of the face— Alpheus Spear, my tenant of the Mount Woolaston farm was here— I took a ride after dinner with Mary and her child; and in the Evening
walked to my brother’s— Mr Price Greenleaf overtook me, and offered his services for arranging my library, or copying papers— He also conversed with me upon my trees, almost all those which I raised from the seed, acorn and nut, having perished— This is owing to the want of continued attention—to my absences every winter, and my return so late in the Season— The winter is especially the time when they most require care— I am then absent and they are totally neglected. In the course of the last Summer, I found also that it was too late in life for me to commence labouring with the spade and hoe. It gave me several sharp touches of rhumatism and lumbago— For pleasure and for advantage so far as I may yet derive any, the most effective resource for me is my books. I read yesterday the third, and this morning the fourth of the Orations against Catiline— The whole four are not so long as the single Oration for Roscius of Ameria— Not one of them could have taken half an hour in the delivery— There is something astonishing in the Scenery of these Speeches— The apostrophe to Catiline with which the first commences is a Coup de Theatre— It seems like an incident purposely devised to kindle and display the Eloquence of the greatest Orator that ever lived. The appearance of Catiline in the Senate, after two Nights of conspiracy for the destruction of the City, is an event scarcely conceivable— Yet had Catiline not been there, no Oration could have been delivered— An incident equally wonderful, and of the same character gave rise to the third Oration—namely the production in the Senate of the intercepted Letters written by the conspirators with Catiline, and the compulsion put upon them to acknowledge their own handwriting. The fourth Oration is upon the same question discussed between Cato and Caesar in Sallust— The Address with which Cicero favours the vote for capital punishment, is the most remarkable part of this effusion.
8. V. Tuesday.

Heavy Showers of rain through the day, with cold weather. Dr Holbrook was here this morning— My wife’s disease, though still very severe begins this day to subside— It has been the most terrific attack of St. Anthony’s fire that I ever witnessed— Alpheus Spear was here and settled his Rent with me to the first of April—and gave me the Deed of Elisha Wild, executed the first of January last, acknowledged and recorded of three Acres of Salt-marsh more or less, adjoining upon the Mount Woolaston farm— He likewise sent me this Evening a Cow— My chief occupation now, next to my reading is, redeeming the arrearages of this Diary, with the increasing difficulty of writing, and now with the distressing illness of my wife, so disturbing the tranquility of the mind necessary for writing, that the record partakes of its infirmities— Its progress is also slackened and at the close of every day I am scarcely more advanced than at the beginning— This morning I commenced reading the Oration for Murena, one of those which I had read and studied when I was first at St. Petersburg in 1781— I have also read the Advertisement of the Abbé Prevot; pre-fixed to his Translation of Middleton’s life of Cicero; and the translation of Middleton’s preface— There are in both, notices of Roman customs, Laws, and Manners
necessary to be known for the perfect understanding of Cicero. And I am looking into a thick Quarto Volume of John Frederic Gronovius de Sestertiis, which I suppose contains a full account of the monies and modes of accounting of the Greeks and Romans. The Book printed at Leyden 1691. is dedicated by James Gronovius, the authors Son, to William the 3d. then king of Great-Britain; just 30 years after the Elzevir Cicero had been dedicated to him as Prince of Orange by Schrevelius. There is a complication in the Roman modes of counting money, and of computing time which I never understood, and which often perplexes me, in reading the Latin authors— The arrangement of the days of the Month into Ides, Nones and Calends, with the custom of reckoning backwards so many days before each of those periods is unnatural and absurd— The forms of counting money, and of denoting the rates of interest, are still more intricate; but the very looking into those books, consumes too much of my time—how shall I study them? and cui bono? Abigail S. Adams came to spend some days with Mary— I took a ride with them towards Evening, and we were overtaken with a drenching shower of rain and hail.
9. V. Wednesday.

Dr Holbrook was here. My wife’s fever is yet very high; and the swelling and inflammation, has spread almost over her whole face— Charles and his wife came out and spent the day with us, but returned this Evening to Boston— I gave Charles one copy of Wailly’s French Translation of Cicero’s select Orations, with the fourth Volume containing the Philippics and Catilinaries by D’Olivet— I have two complete copies of the work, besides the second and third Volumes of another set— Charles urged me to resume the Memoir of my father’s life, which I have already too long neglected— I have in truth here less time at my disposal than at Washington— This is the eighth day since my arrival here; and the arrears even of this diary are as great, as they were when I came into the House— I walked out this Evening, intending to go to my brother’s, but stopping at Mr Whitney’s got engaged in conversation with him till it was time to come home.
10. V. Thursday.

Cold and Showery morning which still confined me to the house. After dinner Dr Bowditch, and Mr Tredwell, the former and present President’s of the association of Mechanics in Boston, came to request me to deliver the introductory Lecture, to the course which is to be given, next Winter— It is to commence in October— The introductory Lectures of the preceding years have been given by Edward Everett, Daniel Webster and Judge Story. I was in hopes I should have escaped this tax, which will give me much trouble and vexation, without credit to myself, or I fear benefit to any one else— I told them, that it would afford me great pleasure to comply with this invitation, which I felt as an honour conferred upon me— That the only consideration which could cause a single moment of hesitation in my mind, was a deep, and sincere distrust of my own qualifications to discharge the duty which I should assume— I was not acquainted with the precise objects of the Mechanic Association; and so far as I had an idea of the courses of Lectures which had been delivered to them; they were subjects with which my mind was not familiar, and towards which not much of my attention had ever been turned. Mr Tredwell said that he would furnish me with the annual Reports upon the
objects of the Institution, which had been published, and they would give me the desired information— Mr Bowditch mentioned my Report upon weights and Measures, as proving that I had been no stranger to the discussion of scientific subjects— I finally requested a few days for consideration, and assured them that I would very cheerfully undertake the task, if I could bring myself to the opinion that I could say any thing worthy of being heard— I planted in the Garden, five Walnuts given me last Winter by Mary Roberdeau, and transplanted several Apple trees, just up from seeds which I sowed last Summer. They came up in clusters, and the day after I arrived, in weeding round some of them, I plucked up one of them by mistake for a weed— I immediately set it out, without expecting it would live, but it is now alive—and thriving. My walnuts, which are very large, I fear have been kept too long— The weather cleared off this afternoon, and I rode with Mary, Mrs. Nowland and the child to the new Meeting-House in Braintree, thence across to Weymouth and back over Penn’s Hill— Returning I stop’d, to visit Mr Marston then at Mr J. Greenleaf’s with a Letter to Mrs Greenleaf, from her Son, William, and then at my brother’s with a Letter from Lieutt. T. B. Adams jr to his mother. Returning home I saw a very brilliant Northern Light; and a luminous Arch from Southeast to Northwest, quite across the Heavens, like that which I had seen in September 1827— The fever and inflammation with which my wife is afflicted subsides very slowly— Dr Holbrook this day intermitted his visit. I finished reading the Oration for Murena, one of the favourites of the Translators. What versatility of Genius! This Oration was delivered in the very crisis of Catiline’s conspiracy— Murena was already elected Consul as one of the Successors of Cicero— Accused of Ambitus, or election bribery, by Servius Sulpitius, and Cato, and defended by Cicero who had himself carried through a law, sharpening the penalties of that Offence— Murena was acquitted, and served his year as Consul— The management of the cause is inimitable— Demosthenes could not have delivered such an Oration. The great struggle of the Speaker is against the weight of character of the accusers; both his personal friends; men of great talents and of admirable virtue— He treats them with the most respectful deference; but gets the laugh upon them both— Sulpicius for his lawyer’s technicalities—Cato for his Stoicism. There is a comparative estimate of military service, the profession of the Law, and popular eloquence, adapted to the state of the question and to Roman customs and opinions— The defence of Murena, upon the facts of alleged bribery, had already been made by Hortensius; and although Cicero at the request of Murena, returned to it, and replied to the charges of the younger Sulpicius and of Posthumius, that part of the Oration is lost. The case that he made upon the facts was doubtless strong; for it is remarkable of Cicero that his management of facts always carries conviction as irresistible as his arguments— You can never part from him without saying he was right.
11. V. Friday.

My wife continues slowly to recover, but still is confined to her bed. Dr Holbrook was again here this morning, and I consulted him upon the state of my own health, which is precarious— He gave me a prescription which I propose to take at my leisure. Mr Brooks with Mr and Mrs Frothingham, and my Son Charles’s wife paid us an afternoon visit— My brother’s wife was here in the Evening, and George W. Beale who makes very inauspicious reports of the failure of business in this Town of Quincy— The Stone-cutters, excepting those at the Railway have all left the Town, and that branch of Industry is entirely at a stand— They have gone to Sandy-Bay, where the Quarry of Stone is close upon the shore, and they can ship it for Norfolk, at a very trifling expence. This has reduced the business upon the Quincy Canal, so that there will be no
dividend upon the Stock; and the charges upon the Neponset Bridge are so great that there will be no dividend for the Stock holders to that. I took a ride this afternoon with Mary, and Abigail S. Adams, to Milton— Hull— Began to read Cicero’s Oration for Publius Sulla— I received Letters yesterday, from my nephew T. B. Adams junr. Dated 27. May at Fort Moultrie, from William Meeteer President of the Company of the Citizens Canal-Line of Steam-boats between Baltimore and Philadelphia, complaining that the Line had been represented to me as a Jackson Line; and denying the fact— And from Stephen Bates, of the 8th. instt. with a Prospectus of a daily Newspaper to be published in Boston, against Free masonry— These two last Letters were probably both written with a view to the answers which they would draw from me— It is scarcely if at all possible for me to answer them with frankness and sincerity, without involving myself again in bitter and frantic political controversy. If I flinch from the questions involved in these Letters—what selfishness and cowardise!— If I meet them, Atè hot from Hell, will be let loose again, not only upon me, but upon my family, upon my wife, my children, my dead father— This is and has been to them and me, the Law, not only of political Life, but of taking any interest in political questions— Let me take the Letters ad referendum, and reflect whether I can answer them insignificantly.
12. V. Saturday.

John Kirke went to Boston this morning, with one of my ponies, for the use of my Son Charles, and came out at noon, with the other; the best of the two, but which has been sick to the danger of death with the glanders. Kirke was charged with Sundry Commissions, and an experiment of a Cook came out in the Stage this afternoon— Visit from Mr Daniel Greenleaf who is recovering from a violent inflammatory fever, which he was for some days not expected to survive. He speaks despondingly of the prospects of the Seasons—that is, of the promised superabundance of the crops. The Hay and corn were said last autumn to have been cut off by the drought, in great part of Maine and New-Hampshire— Yet great importations, are now made of Hay from both those States into Boston, cheaper than the same Article can be furnished from this place— Mr Greenleaf has thirty tons of last years hay, with which he knows not what to do. Mr Nathaniel Curtis was here, with a short Letter, of no significancy from Petty Vaughan of 31. March— We discussed the papers prepared by J. Lowell to be executed by the Executors of Ward N Boylston—to Thomas and John Baring, and Joshua Bates, to recover the monies received by Petty Vaughan, from the French Government as part of the Estate of Thomas Boylston— I agreed to meet Mr Curtis at my Son Charles’s Office, at 11. O’Clock next Tuesday Morning, there, with Mr Boylston to execute the papers: I told Mr Curtis I would write a separate Letter to the Barings and Bates, as Administrator upon the Estate of Thomas Boylston; and I desired him to consult Mr Lowell upon the question, whether by a power of Attorney from Moses Gill as Executor of his Uncle, a suit could not be maintained in England, upon Petty Vaughan’s Bond as Administrator of Thomas Boylston, for that portion of the monies received from the French Government which was due to the Estate of Lieutenant Governor Gill; and if it could, whether a power should not be obtained from Gill, as Executor, for that purpose. Mr Curtis supposed it would be necessary to sell some part of the Estate of Ward N. Boylston in this Country; to pay the pressing demands upon the Estate for which he is already somewhat in advance— It has not been practicable to sell advantageously my part of the Lands either at Princeton or at Charlestown. Mr Quincy the President of Harvard University
called, and gave me a copy of the three Volumes just published, of the Catalogue of the Library of the University— A fourth Volume, containing the maps and Charts is yet to come out— The Catalogue is first Alphabetical, in two Volumes, without discrimination of Subject or size annexing the format, to each work— The third Volume is a systematic Index, in which the works are divided into six Classes, and each Class, excepting the last, works relating to America, into several Sections. The Preface to the first Volume of the Catalogue, contains a brief account of the formation of the Library, and notices of the donors, in which my father’s name and mine are included— But Mr Quincy said there was no trace among the papers in his Office of the donations; or of what books they consisted— I told him I had no very distinct recollection of them; but there were three books, of which I could speak with certainty—Van Loon’s Medallic History of the Netherlands, Catrou and Rouillés Roman History, and the Collection of Memoirs of the History of France— We found them all in the Catalogue, but the Collection of Memoirs incomplete, and he said that some years since they sold their duplicates, and the History of Catron and Rouillé was one of them, which he himself purchased— It was an unbound copy, mine was bound. I observed that a new Treasurer had been elected— Mr Ward in the place of Mr Francis, resigned— The cause of which, he said was ill health— I thought Mr Quincy spoke in a less sanguine tone of the prospects of improvement at the College, than he did last year— He asked something about the annuity from W. N. Boylston’s benefactions; which I told him I had spoken of to Mr Curtis this morning. He spoke also of the Account of Administration, on my father’s Estate; and said he would attend at the next Probate Court at Quincy. The present judge is Sherman Leland—judge Robbins having died in the course of the last year. I rode this afternoon with Mary and Abigail S. Adams, towards Weymouth and to the Mount Wollaston beach— We left Abigail at her father’s.
13. IV:30. Sunday.

There was a thunder shower this morning; which roused me before the Sun— Cold Rain all the Morning. Heard Mr. Pierpont this morning from Exodus 20.5. “For I the Lord thy God am a jealous God.”—and in the afternoon from Hebrews 11.4. “he, being dead, yet speaketh.” I do not remember having heard him preach before; and his reputation being very high, neither of his Sermons entirely fulfilled my expectations— His manner and delivery are cold; though he is an elegant Poet— His Style is ornamental, but not remarkable for energy, or precision— His stamp is not deep, or my mind was not in the proper state to receive its impression— He dined with me, and I collected more thoughts from his conversation than from his discourses— He made several remarks upon the book of Job, which he thinks was not written by Moses—nor even a Hebrew Book. It is Arabian— No one of the names of the actors in it, are mentioned in any other part of the Scriptures; nor is there any allusion in any part of the Book to the Mosaic History— Mr Pierpont believes Job to have been a descendant of Abraham; but not of Jacob. He thinks that the name of Satan, was borrowed by the Hebrews from the Chaldeans. Upon my remarking that the first occasion upon which Satan is named is in the account of David’s numbering the People; he said it was—in the Book of Chronicles. 1.21.1. probably written during or after the Babylonian captivity—but that in the other account of the same event—2. Samuel 24.1. the purpose of David is said to have been moved by the Lord— With regard to a future State; the ideas and opinions of the Jews appear to have been cotemporaneous with those of the Heathens— It was not communicated with the Law from Sinai— A dim and obscure conception of it, is found in the
evocation of the shade of Samuel— Something more distinct in the Book of Daniel; and still more so in the apocryphal books of the Maccabees— The same difference is perceptible between the Elysian fields of Homer, and those of Virgil. I spoke of the prophecies in the Old Testament, the application of which is made in the New Testament to the person, and mission of Christ; most particularly that of Isaiah 7.14. applied Matthew 1.23. of this prophecy as first delivered to Ahaz, and all the circumstances attending it, Mr Pierpont gave from memory a very exact account, and appeared to think that there had been a fulfilment of it at the time; although that is not mentioned in the narrative— The events announced by the prophet, and of which the birth of the child from a virgin was the miraculous sign, did happen and are recorded, and it is to be presumed that the sign itself was accomplished— I asked him if he thought the prophet Isaiah himself had any conception of the application which his prophesy was ultimately to receive; or whether the Prophets were like Hamlet’s flute, which he presents to his associates, and tells them if they will give it breath, and govern its vantages, it would discourse most excellent music— Mr Pierpont said that was a great and very difficult question— I mentioned to him the strange and wonderful passage in one of Plato’s dialogues where Socrates says that there must come a special messenger from Heaven, to reveal the future state of the human Soul—and I noticed the weakness of the argument of immortality in the Phaedon— But Mr Pierpont is not more familiar with Plato, than judge Story— My brother was here, in the afternoon, and Mr Thomas Greenleaf in the Evening.
14. IV.30. Monday.

My Son Charles and his wife came out from Boston, upon a visit to us for some days. In the Evening I called at my brother’s, where were Mrs Rufus Dawes, (judge Cranch’s daughter Elizabeth[)], and Louisa C. Smith. I met Mr Edward Miller, to whom I intended to have paid a visit; and afterwards I went to Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s. The Evening was thus consumed— I wrote this afternoon, as Administrator de bonis non, of Thomas Boylston with the Will annexed, a Letter to Thomas and John Baring and Joshua Bates, to be sent with the Letter and Power, and Statement of facts of the Executors of Ward N Boylston— I have read since Thursday the Orations for Publius Sulla, for Archias the Poet; and this morning began that for Lucius Flaccus Sulla, had been together with Autronius a candidate for the Consulship, two years before Cicero— Their competitors, Lucius Cotta, and Lucius Torquatus, had impeached them for bribery, (ambitus) and both of them had been condemned—whereby Cotta and Torquatus had been proclaimed Consuls. The first conspiracy of Catiline immediately afterwards followed, but proved abortive. After the suppression of the second conspiracy of Catiline by Cicero, when Consul, and under his immediate Successors, Silanus and Murena, Sulla was accused by the Son of Torquatus, as an accomplice of Catiline in both the conspiracies. With regard to the first he had been defended by Hortensius, and this Oration is the defence by Cicero, not only of Sulla, but of himself upon the second; for young Torquatus in his accusation of Sulla, had very rudely and severely censured Cicero for undertaking the defence of Sulla. A full half of the Oration is embraced therefore by the Orator’s vindication of himself. Torquatus had charged him first with gross inconsistency, after his extraordinary zeal for the suppression of the conspiracy, in becoming the defender of Sulla—to which Cicero replies by enquiring why Torquatus confines the charge to him? why he did not extend
it to Hortensius, who had also defended Sulla. He declares with much solemnity his own belief of Sulla’s innocence, and that no evidence had been exhibited to him of his guilt— Torquatus who was of a high Patrician family, had sneered at Cicero’s birth at Arpinum, and said he was the third foreign king of Rome— Cicero repels the imputation very indignantly, tells Torquatus that all cannot be patricians; and turns the tables upon him by shewing that his own mother came from one of the municipal cities, so that upon his own principle he was himself a foreigner— But Torquatus had affectedly lamented the execution of the conspirators; and thereby contributed to inflame the popular prejudices against Cicero for that act— Upon this point Cicero replies with painfully suppressed anger, and a boast of moderation, mingled with threats— Sulla was acquitted; and there was in fact no substantial Evidence against him; but he was one of the bad men of the age, and lived to be one of the Lieutenant Generals of Caesar at the Battle of Pharsalia.
15. IV. Tuesday.

I went to Boston with Charles and his wife, and Abigail S. Adams— Left the Ladies at his house. Walking to his house, Judge Hall overtook us— I asked him if it was necessary to return an inventory and account of Administration, when there was nothing to return— He said no— But that on returning to the Probate Office the Instruction to Account, it might be proper to state what property of Thomas Boylston might be expected to be received hereafter, and from what source it might come— At Charles’s Office, I met Mr Nathaniel Curtis and Mrs Boylston— We executed and acknowledged before Thomas Welsh junr. Justice of Peace, a Power, as Executors of Ward N. Boylston, and on my part as Administrator of Thomas Boylston, to Thomas Baring John Baring, and Joshua Bates, a Power to recover the monies in the hands of Petty Vaughan, in duplicate copies; and Mr Curtis took them, to get them authenticated by the Governor at the Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth: we signed also in duplicates the Letter with the Statement of facts to accompany the Power, prepared by J. Lowell— Mr Curtis said he had mentioned to Mr Lowell the demand of Gill, upon T. Boylston Estate, on account of the sum recovered from the French Government, and Mr Lowell thought it would be proper to obtain a Power from Gill— I engaged to draw one up to be taken by Charles to-morrow Morning to Mr Curtis, who will go to Princeton, and get it executed by Mr Gill. Mrs Boylston said there was a Note from Gill to her husband, of one thousand dollars, to set off against the claim of his when recovered— The Power referred to an Account of Petty Vaughan, acknowledging the receipt of the sum from the French Government, as annexed— This account was among the papers in my possession— Charles made a copy of it this evening— After my business done, I called at Wells and Lilly’s shop, and took the 84th. number of the English Quarterly Review, and bespoke the subsequent numbers of this and of the Edinburgh Review, to be delivered to me here instead of at Washington until next October— I strayed also to several other shops and made purchases of sundry Articles necessary for the use of the household; among which a pair of house Scales and Iron weights from four pounds to 1/4 of an ounce. I met in the Streets Mr John Hubbard, and Captain Morgan of the Navy. We dined with Charles— Miss Julia Gorham was there— We all returned to Quincy before Evening— It was the first day of full Summer heat of this Season— I was unable to write— I yet adhere to my Ciceronian studies, and on Sunday read the Oration for Archias—This is the organic law of human Literature— If Cicero had never atchieved any thing else but the composition of this Speech he would have been an eminent benefactor of his kind. The occasion of its delivery was a captious question made by some malignant dunce named Gratius
whether Archias was a Roman citizen— He was a native of Antioch, and had been made a Citizen of Heraclea in Sicily— By a Law of Silvanus and Carbo, otherwise called the Law Plautia-Papiria, persons inscribed as Citizens of the confederate Citizens (of which Heraclea was one[)], if when the Law was enacted they had their domicil in Italy, acquired the right of Roman Citizens by appearing before the Praetor, and claiming it within 60 days. All this Archias had done, but the public Register of Heraclea had been burnt in the Italic War; and there was a lack of evidence by the Record. It was supplied by the Testimony of respectable witnesses— The facts were sufficiently proved, and Cicero says not much about them: but the panegyric upon Literature, the profound philosophy and the connection of the arts with the progress of human virtue are original in this speech, and form with it an epoch in the advancement of civilization and morals.
16. IV:15. Wednesday.

I drafted a Power of Attorney, to be executed by Moses Gill, as Executor of his Uncle’s Will, to me as Administrator of Thomas Boylston for the recovery of the money received By Petty Vaughan— Charles took it into Boston, and gave it to Mr Curtis, together with the copy of the Statement of account to be annexed to the Power of Attorney to the Baring’s and Bates— Charles returned here to dine; and after dinner we commenced making out the Catalogue of my Library— We commence according to the locality, and spent three hours upon it this afternoon. Mary and Charles’s wife went and took tea at my brother’s. Alexander and Edward Everett were here. The morning was warm—followed by a chilly East wind— Then a light thunder shower, and a sultry evening. My wife is still confined to her chamber and almost entirely to her bed. Edward Everett gave me a pamphlet copy of his speech in the House of Representatives, on the 19th. of May against the Bill for the removal of the Indians, and I have received from Daniel Treadwell a Letter, and several pamphlets relating to the Mechanics Institution in Boston; but they give me no encouragement to undertake the delivery of the Introductory Lecture next October. I finished reading the Oration for Flaccus. He had been one of the Praetors, when Cicero was Consul and was among the most active and efficient of his Assistants in suppressing the conspiracy of Catiline; afterwards he had been three years Governor of the Province of Asia, and at the expiration of that Service, was prosecuted by Decimus Laelius de repetundis; that is for illegal extortion upon the inhabitants of the Province, which included Greece. The Law was provided to compel the restitution for monies or other property taken unlawfully; but the Roman Governor, had numberless modes of plundering the people— This prosecution, Cicero considers, as instigated by his enemies, and intended for a prelude to a direct attack upon him— He tells the judges that they are trying, not the cause of a few obscure provincial witnesses brought there upon compassion; but their own cause—that of their wives and children, of their Country; of the whole Roman People— That they are in effect trying over again the conspiracy of Catiline— A considerable part of this Oration is lost— The defence consists first in amplification of the previous good character of Flaccus— Secondly of his most important services in overthrowing Catiline’s conspiracy— Thirdly in a general impeachment of the credibility of all the witnesses against him; and fourthly in a refutation of particular charges, and a scrutiny of the characters of the witnesses by name. It is not the practice of Cicero, to spare the characters of witnesses who testify against his Clients
and in this case he treats them with great severity. There is in the fourth Section, a very remarkable character given of the Greeks as a Nation— He allows them literature, discipline in many arts, pleasantness of discourse, shrewdness of genius—eloquence, and other indefinite merits—but denies them veracity, and all credibility in testimony. He treats the Greeks of Asia Minor with still greater severity, and quotes a sarcastic proverb against each of the four Nations, the Phrygians, Mysians, Carians and Lydians— There is a passage in the 28th. Section concerning the Jews which is not intelligible to me— He calls their Religion a barbarous superstition— Flaccus was acquitted.
17. IV:30. Thursday.

A very warm Night; and the weather continuing this morning at high Summer heat, I took a bath at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf, and swam from the upper to the lower wharf— It being the first time for the Season—the swimming distance was almost too great, and I returned well wearied— Charles and his wife left us for a visit to Medford— I planted a sixth Pennsylvanian Walnut, but they have been so carelessly kept, that the germ has withered; they float upon water, and the shells have split open. I likewise planted fourteen peach stones, which have been kept over winter, but almost all which sunk in Water— My fruit-trees, which I have attempted to raise from the stone and seed, perish in two different ways—in Summer, by the heat of the Sun, and in winter by the frost— From this fate are exempted, in a great measure the Horse Chesnuts—the Elms—Peaches, Plums, Apples and Apricots— But very few of the Oaks; and much to my surprize hitherto none of the Hickory Walnuts— It is indispensable to guard the young trees the first, and second Winter against the effect of the frosts, and this, not being here in the winter I have never done— Very few of my trees therefore survive— There is an enormous difference in the growth of trees of the same kind— One of the Horse Chesnuts, planted in the Summer house cellar in 1826. is now five feet high; others are 3 and 4 feet— In my Nursery there are a number, but none of them more than one foot above ground. The Stocks of many of the trees, after the first year become distorted— The stems of the Oaks run up excessively Slender, and the leaves, unnaturally large— For these and many other distempers of infancy which I have observed, I know not the remedy. Some of my walnuts which had died to the root, and come up again in the Summer house-cellar, have been killed by the Sun—others are saved by the Sheltering leaves of the Horse-chesnuts— Farrar has sowed the Oaks that I purchased the last Summer, in the Nursery, and they have come up, but look very thin and poor, and almost smothered with weeds— I paid an Evening visit to my next door neighbour George W. Beale who is a good farmer and planter of trees— But he gives formidable accounts of the insects which swarm among them— The rose-bugs, are just now come to prey upon the Roses which are in full bloom— They swarm also upon the leaves of the Elm, which Mr Beale says is attacked by a more formidable enemy in the form of a large black worm of the Caterpillar kind— He says too that the Caterpillar and the Canker worm are both now very destructive to the apple orchards in this neighbourhood— It would be worthy of the agricultural and horticultural Societies to institute formal researches and enquiries into the natural history of fruit trees, and of the insects which prey upon them. For myself, I shall probably continue, as long as my life and health will admit to sow and plant every Summer seeds Stones and Acorns, the Trees from which will continue to perish, by frost and by Sun, by insect and by disease; all for want of continued attention and systematic pursuit— I am yet convinced that much useful service to the Country might thus be performed, by the raising of forest trees; but it would require a permanency of property, not adapted to our political Institutions and Laws; with us each Generation looks only to itself.
18. IV:15 Friday.

Charles and his wife returned from their visit to Medford; and after dinner we continued taking the Catalogue of my Library— It engages us from immediately after dinner till tea time: three hours— My brother’s two daughters were here. I spent an hour of the Evening at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s— My brother and his daughters with Mr Gourgas were there— Coll. and Mrs Quincy paid us a visit while I was out this Evening— They came yesterday to President Quincy’s Seat in this Town to spend the Summer. I read yesterday the Oration to the Senate, and this day that to the People after his return from exile— In the year of Rome 696. Lucius Calpurnius Piso and Aulus Gabinius being Consuls, the fifth year after that of Cicero’s Consulate, and the year immediately after that of Julius Caesar and Bibulus, Publius Clodius had obtained a decree of the People against Cicero, interdicting him from fire and water, and confiscating his Estates— The pretext for this was, that Cicero had caused Roman Citizens the accomplices of Catiline to be put to death without trial and contrary to Law— Clodius had accomplished this by a Series of the most profligate and outrageous acts—but Clodius was throughout the whole transaction, merely the tool of Caesar; and could not have succeeded without base connivance on the part of Pompey and Crassus— It was at the time of the first Triumvirate— To effect his purpose Clodius a Patrician and Senator, had got himself adopted as the Son of a Plebeian young enough to be his Son; and then had got elected a tribune of the People. The decree was obtained by violence in a tumultuous assembly of the people— Cicero might have defended himself with the assistance of his friends, but it would have made a civil War, and he preferred going into exile. He was recalled about 16 months afterwards; and delivered the Oration to the Senate to thank them for their exertions in his favour— In the first Letter of the fourth book of his Epistles to Atticus he gives a very particular account of his return, and mentions his oration to the Senate on the Nones or 5th. of September, the day after he arrived at Rome— It is full of thanks, and praise to the Consuls of that year Lentulus Spinther, and Metellus Nepos; of seven Praetors, of whom, especially Milo and Sextius, and of eight tribunes of the People—but his invective against the Consuls of the preceding year, is extremely violent, and scurrilous. He represents Gabinius as an effeminate Epicurean, and abuses Piso for the swarthiness of his complexion. The Oration to the People, was delivered if at-all, two days after that to the Senate— Many passages in both Orations are the same— The praise of Pompey is too extravagant; and indeed his discourse concerning persons, both laudatory and vituperative, is exaggerated to absurdity. Sounding like dedications to kings.
19. IV:15— Saturday— Sun rose

Charles went into Boston this morning; and returned to dine. Lieutenant Governor Winthrop with his daughter, and Judge Hall, with George Blake paid morning visits— Blake said Mr Webster had told him that there was a meeting of the Members of Congress friendly to the last Administration a few days before the close of the Session, to consider whether it would be expedient to make a nomination of a Candidate for the Presidency in opposition to General Jackson; and it was concluded rather to let the first nomination come from a State Legislature— It was confidently expected that the Administration would lose its majorities in five of the State Legislatures the ensuing Winter Kentucky, Ohio, Indiana, Louisiana and Maryland— The nomination, it was
expected would come from Maryland— Mr Webster is in very sanguine Spirits, and considers the Administration, as almost in a state of dissolution. He says there is not a person at Washington who appears to entertain the least respect either for Mr Calhoun or Mr Van Buren. I said I thought Mr Webster had been in the habit of hearing the partizans of each of those men, speak of the other and I have great doubts whether the Administration will lose majorities in five of the State Legislatures so soon— I continued working this afternoon with Charles upon the Catalogue of my books, and towards evening walked to call at Mr Edward Miller’s; but he was not at home. I spent an hour at my brother’s— Charles brought me out from Mr Curtis the mortgage of the Trustees of the Tremont Theatre to W. N. Boylston, for 10,000 dollars, which he has agreed to sell to the Treasurer of Harvard College, and he requested that I would come in to Boston next Monday to execute the Assignment with the other Executors. The loan is for twenty-one years from the 1st. of March 1827. and is at an interest of five per cent a year, payable semi-annually.
20. IV:30. Sunday.

North-east Storm. Rain all the Morning— Heard Mr Crafts of Bridgwater This morning from Psalm 30.5. “In his favour is life.” and in the afternoon from 2. Samuel 12.7 “Thou art the man.”— The texts were more impressive than the Sermons— Moral discourses upon benevolence have no doubt at all times their merit. Most of the preachers with whom Mr Whitney is associated, preach them all together— They are apt to dispose the hearer to sleep— They are perhaps easier to write than historical, doctrinal or controversial Sermons— But they do not irresistibly fix the attention— Of all Sermons that I have ever heard or read, those of Sterne, have left the deepest mark upon my memory— They are almost all parables— Jesus himself delivered most of his Instructions in parables; and it would be a suitable enquiry for a Christian Minister, whether this may not be considered as demonstrative proof that it is the most effective of all modes of Instruction. There are in the Scriptures numerous individual characters of whom something is related sufficient to form the subject of a parable—which with a little exertion of the imagination may be wrought into a narrative—decorated with argument, and pointed with a moral— Without persons there can be no pathos— Abstraction has no blood. Next to the historical Sermons, those of argument illustrating obscurities of natural or revealed religion are most agreeable to me— Massillon and Tillotson are, next to Sterne those of whose Sermons I retain the most durable Memory— My father warmly recommended to me those of Butler, particularly the Sermons upon human Nature; and upon the Character of Balaam—and also his Analogy— I read them about twenty years ago, but without retaining much of their contents— I propose therefore to give them another perusal, and this day took up an Edition of the Analogy, published at London about the year 1780— I read only a long preliminary discourse, being a defence of Bishop Butler against a charge which seems to have been made against him after his death; that he became a convert to popery; and died in Communion with the Church of Rome— His memory was first vindicated by Archbishop Secker, a Charge to the Clergy of his diocese, dwelling earnestly on external Religion, and a crucifix which he had laid in his chapel gave rise to the rumour, for the truth of which no more substantial Evidence was ever produced.
21— IV.30. Monday.

I intended to have gone in to Boston with Charles this morning, and the Chaise was brought for us to the door, but there was a North east storm coming and it began just then to rain. We both concluded to stay and employed all the morning till dinner time in assorting the Books of the Library, and continuing the Catalogue— We had a fire in the dining room, and the Storm continued with heavy rain, and some thunder and lightening till approaching Sunset— I began yesterday to read Cicero’s Oration for his house, and continued this day. I brought up also the arrears of this Journal, and should henceforth be at liberty to pursue the occupation which I long since determined to undertake; upon which I did so little last Summer and have since entirely neglected— The very magnitude of the work deters me from the persevering application to it which it requires— There is a luxurious idleness in the possession of a considerable Library, and which I now find irresistible. While I take the Catalogue of my books; every volume that I take down to have its title recorded tempts me to look into it, and leads to a multitude of enquiries which waste time— I have a Letter from Dr Waterhouse, in which he mentions that he has sent to the Printer, his essay to prove that Lord Chatham was the author of Junius. A pertinacious attempt has lately been made to prove that Horne Tooke was the author of that literary prodigy— Nothing in literary or political History has ever more powerfully displayed the operation of Mystery upon the minds of men than the Letters of Junius. He declares himself that his secret is his own, and that it shall perish with him— This declaration has probably sharpened the curiosity of many readers, and has produced pamphlet after pamphlet, and volume after volume to fix the authorship, upon every possible person— Of the internal evidence of the Letters, there are two things which render it improbable that Chatham was the author— The panegyric upon himself—and the positive and explicit dissent from his avowed opinions upon no less a question than that between Great Britain and the American Colonies. The violence, the ingratitude, the duplicity, the malignity, the moral perversity, and the religious infidelity with which Junius abounds, were not in the known character of Lord Chatham, who if the fact should be proved upon him would lose reputation for virtue without gaining any thing upon the score of talent.
22. IV:30. Tuesday.

I went in to Boston with Charles, this morning, and returned to dine at Quincy. I called at Mr James H. Foster’s, and at A. H. Everett’s. Mr Foster is recovering from sickness— I had a conversation upon subjects of Literature and Politics with Mr Everett. We spoke of the proposed memoir of the Life of William Tudor, concerning whom he mentioned several facts of which he has lately acquired information— There are yet not sufficient materials upon which to commence the work— Mr Everett expressed some dissatisfaction that the members of Congress friendly to the election of Mr Clay to the next Presidency, did not make a formal nomination of him before the close of the late Session of Congress— He thinks it was prevented by Mr Webster, who he supposes has views upon that office for himself. He says that Mr Johnston of Louisiana, was very anxious for a nomination which would have been made had it not been prevented by Mr Webster
I told him that if Mr Webster had advised against a nomination, under expectations of being himself a Candidate, I thought he would be disappointed, but his advice against a nomination by members of Congress was good— Any Congressional nomination will injure the man in whose favour it will be made— I said it was impossible to foresee what the fluctuations of popular opinion would be— Hitherto there were symptoms of changes of opinion among the members of Congress, but none among the People— These could be indicated only by the Elections, and it would be unsafe policy to anticipate them— I had great doubts whether the majorities in the Legislatures of five States would be changed by the approaching Elections, and was far from certain that the next Legislature of Kentucky would nominate Mr Clay in opposition to the re-election of General Jackson— The whole strength of the present Administration rests upon his personal popularity, founded upon his military services— He has surrendered the Indians to the States, within the bounds of which they are located—this will confirm and strengthen his popularity in those States—especially as he has burdened the Union with the expence of removing and indemnifying the Indians— He has taken practical ground against internal improvements and domestic Industry—which will strengthen him in all the Southern States. He has as might have been expected thrown his whole weight into the Slave-holding scale; and that interest is so compact, so cemented and so fervent in action, that there is every prospect it will overpower the discordant and loosely patched policy of the free. The Cause of internal improvement will sink; and that of domestic Industry will fall with or after it— There is at present a great probability that this system will be supported by a majority of the People— If the Presidential election should be connected with this question and turn upon it Mr Clay will be the Candidate of internal improvement, and of the manufactures. But it will be a minority. The anti-masonick spirit will operate against him in New-York, and perhaps elsewhere— Everett said that he had been solicited to publish in the North-American Review an Anti-masonic Article in answer to a violent masonic article in the last number of Walsh’s Review; but he had declined— But he said he was assured the anti-masons here would support Mr Clay— But Clay is a Mason, and will not take any ground against them— It was near one O’Clock when I left Mr Everett, and met Mr Curtis at my Son Charles’s Office. He told me that Mr Francis the Treasurer of Harvard College, who had intended to purchase the mortgage of the Trustees of the Tremont Theatre had altered his mind and now declined taking it— Returned with Charles to Quincy to dine; and devoted the afternoon to the Catalogue— My brother and his wife were here in the Evening. I found myself again with an excessive bad cold, for which I took at Night Dr Holbrook’s Prescription— My wife has so far recovered that she is able to ride out— William Sturgis and E. Cruft were here this morning while I was at Boston.
23. IV:30. Wednesday—

I was quite unwell the whole day with my Cold, which again threatens my lungs— Sore throat, hoarseness and Catarrh, are constantly returning upon me; and for the last nine Months I have never been entirely free from them— Charles went to Boston and returned here to dine— From dinner till tea time we employed upon the Catalogue, and I took a ride with my wife and two daughters in Law, in the Carriage— I yesterday finished reading Cicero’s Oration for his House, and this morning began upon that concerning the answers of the Haruspices— The Oration for his House, was one of those in which Cicero most prided himself— In the second Epistle of the fourth Book of the Letters to Atticus, he relates the circumstances and on which it was delivered— After he went into Exile, Clodius had demolished his house, and to prevent the possibility that the Sand upon which it had stood should ever be restored to him, had caused it to be consecrated by religious solemnities, and a temple to be built upon it, consecrated to Liberty. But now the friends of Cicero insisted not only that Cicero’s land should be restored to him, but that his house should be rebuilt at the public expense. The Senate referred the question, as to the religious consecration of the place to
the College of Pontiffs, before whom this Oration was delivered. In his letter to Atticus he says that if he never was eloquent upon any other occasion he was upon that, and that he should send it to him soon; that it might be useful to the young men of his time. It is among the Orations of the French translation of Wailly, but it is not one of those which I think the most pleasing. The first part of it has no relation to the question upon trial— It is a defence of the Senate, and of Cicero himself for having conferred upon Pompey, extraordinary powers to provide supplies of corn, for the people— A power for which there was apparently no necessity; and which became the cause of much after usurpation— The rest of the Oration, turns chiefly upon objections to mere formalities of performance in religious ceremonies— Clodius could not dedicate a Temple to Liberty, because he was not lawfully a Tribune— He was no Tribune, because he had not been legally adopted: because the consecration had been pronounced, not by the whole College of Pontiffs but only by one; a young man, a family relation of Clodius—unwillingly—and in an irregular member—finally because, no private property could be lawfully consecrated, but by virtue of a special edict of the People— This last reason was all sufficient, for Clodius had acted without any such edict of the People; and the rest of the argument appears to be superfluous— It is surprizing how the Orator upon such a subject could excite any interest at-all—and whatever interest there ever was, is extinguished by the abolition of the Religion under which the consecration had taken place. Clodius was a profligate, and unprincipled hypocrite, as well in religion as in Politics— His profanation of the mysteries of the Bona Dea, proved his shameless contempt of the Religion of his Country— The greater part of this Oration is a continued strain of invective against him— In Section 35. a bitter stroke of Irony, in reply to a sneer of Clodius, charging him with affecting the Power of Jupiter— In Section 41. a beautiful philosophical Sentiment upon piety to the Gods— In Section 31. he styles the Gracchi most seditious men— He had spoken of them more favourably in one of the Orations against the Agrarian Law of Rullus— In speaking or writing of historical Events and characters it is well to remember at one time what has been said or written at another.
24. IV:15. Thursday.

My Cold and hoarseness continues; and oppression upon the lungs— My wife, who had much recovered, was again this day quite unwell. A Mr Sergeant of the City of New-York, with a person from Tioga County, called to pay a visit of curiosity— The former told me that Mr John Sergeant of Philadelphia was his Cousin— He also announced to me his design of making a tour in Europe. Deacon Spear and his brother called here this afternoon. Louisa C. Smith and Abigail S. Adams dined with us; Louisa brought me two bundles of copies of my beloved mother’s Letters; with some manuscript extracts of mine made from my youthful readings, while I was studying Law at Newbury-Port. I finished reading the Oration upon the Answers of the Haruspices; which is still more connected with the Religious superstitions of the age than the Oration for his house— A Story had been gotten up, and circulated to the great dismay of the masters of the world, that strange subterraneous noises, and a horrible clashing of Arms had been heard in the neighbourhood of Rome— The alarm was so great that the Senate referred the question to the Haruspices, what this new Wonder be must be understood to portend— They consulted the Etruscan Books, and answered the reference of the Senate, in writing— They declared that the Gods were highly offended, and that supplications to them must immediately decreed— They specified several transgressions which had been committed; among which one was, that sacred and religious places
had been profaned— Clodius the infamous and perpetual persecutor of Cicero immediately seized upon this part of the declaration, and attempted to persuade the people, that it applied to the restitution of Cicero’s House and Land— In this Oration, delivered in the Senate, Cicero retorts the charge upon him, and by a special analysis of every part of the Answers argues with great force and ingenuity, that it all applies to the crimes of Clodius— We know at present that all this was imaginary, but from the earnestness with which he argues the case, we cannot forbear to believe that he was very sincere in his convictions, and really thought that the Gods were denouncing Clodius from under-ground— There appears to have been no question for discussion— The object of Cicero, was immediately to discredit the pretension of Clodius; and to suppress instantly the attempt to enlist the religious fears of the People against him and his house— He proves as clearly as possible that his house was under no religious consecration, and he exposes the impudence and inconsistency of Clodius in pretending any concern for religion; with the crimes under which he was living. The answers of the Aruspices indicated a convulsed and gloomy state of public feeling, and Cicero himself largely partakes of it— The peroration is full of dejection and despondency— He despairs of the Public Freedom— Mr Bailey was here, but I did not see him; being in the garden when he came, and they thought me gone out.
25. IV:15. Friday.

Mr Bailey was here with Mr Martin, who is the Postmaster at Milton; but who came as Chairman of a Committee of Arrangements from a Company of Citizens of Quincy and Milton, who propose on Monday the 5th. of July to celebrate the Anniversary of Independence at the new Railway Church— There is to be an Oration at 12. O’Clock, by the Revd. Mr Chandler, and a dinner at 3. at the Railway house— Mr Martin left with me a written invitation— I told him, with suitable acknowledgments for the favour that I apprehended the state of my health would not admit of my attendance— I observed that I would send him a written answer if it was desired; but that I wished to avoid all public meetings— He said my verbal answer would be sufficient— Abigail S. Adams came with Mr and Mrs Davis, and Mrs Derby and Mrs Minot came together— Davis said that Mr Webster had yesterday received a Letter from Mr Clay, who approved of the omission to nominate him at the West as entirely satisfactory. I thought the state of public opinion would be collected from the result of the elections which will commence the next Month in Louisiana, and then follow successively in the other Western States till the Winter— Nothing is more delusive than anticipations of the event of elections, and expectations of great changes in popular suffrages are almost always disappointed— I suppose that the sacrifice of the Indians, and of the interest of internal improvement and domestic Industry, will strengthen rather than weaken the popularity of the present Administration— I have cherished the principle and the system of internal improvement under a conviction that it was for this Nation the only path to increasing comforts and well being, to honour, to glory, and finally to the general improvement of the condition of mankind— This system has had its fluctuations from the time of the Establishment of the present Constitution of the United States— During the Administration of Mr Monroe, it was constantly acquiring strength in Congress and in the public opinion— It was then favoured by Calhoun and Lowndes, both of whom had hopes of rising upon it, and with them the State of South-Carolina was devoted to it— The combination in Congress, became by their means so strong that it overpowered the resistance of Mr
Monroe, and produced the Act of Congress of April 1824— The Slave-holders of the South have since discovered that it will operate against their interests— Calhoun has turned his back upon it; and Jackson who to promote his election and obtain Western votes truckled to it for a time, has now taken his decided stand against it— My devotion to it has sharpened all the fangs of envy and malice against it, and multitudes oppose it, only because its success would contribute to my reputation— The cause will no doubt survive me; and if the union is destined to continue, will no doubt ultimately triumph— At present it is desperate— Charles went to Boston this morning and returned to dine— We continued the Catalogue, after dinner.
26. IV. Saturday.

Charles and his wife left us this morning to go and spend a week with Mr Brooks at Medford. I received a Letter from Cumberland D. Williams at Baltimore, making enquiries concerning a Letter which he mentions having written to me in 1810. when I was at St. Petersburg, upon a claim against the Danish Government, for capture of a vessel of which he was Supercargo. I have no recollection of this case, but answered Mr Williams’s Letter, and wrote to my Son John, to examine my files, and Letter-Books of that time, which are at Washington— Charles’s absence disengages me from the continuation of my Catalogue, and leaves the after part of the day unoccupied— I resumed writing the Memoir of my father’s life, which has been neglected since the second of last October. Mr and Mrs John and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf were here this Evening— When I came here last Summer, I undertook to labour personally in my garden with the spade and hoe. Perhaps at the age of thirty, this discipline might have been found practicable— I persevered in it, till repeated attacks of rhumatism and lumbago warned me that these labours were not suitable for me, and I desisted— I now visit my garden from time to time, but without the spade or hoe— The two bearing cherry trees are just now stripped of their last fruit, before it was ripe—partly by the birds; and partly for family consumption in tarts. I have this day buried, in one of my old seed boxes, a handfull of Stones from these cherries to ascertain if they will vegetate. My Summer house cellar, is nearly full of trees two and three years old, and most of them now fit for transplanting. The growth of the Oaks, Elms and Horse-chesnuts chiefly demands observation. The shoot of the Oak, of the present year has recently put forth in two or three of the Trees, and not in the others. A twig of willow that I stuck down, two years since took root, and are now so flourishing that eight or ten days since I cut off its stem, say six or eight inches above the ground. I mark this day three new shoots coming out upon the stump— The most remarkable fact, of my young Oaks is the smallness of their Stems—and so it is of the Apples, peaches, and Plums. Of Cherries, I believe there is but one living which came up from the Stone.
27. V. Sunday.

Mrs. Nowland went into Boston this morning with John Kirke to attend Mass, at the Catholic Church— Returned, between two and three, afternoon. I heard Mr Green, a young man settled at Lechmere’s Point— His morning text was from John 20.29. [“]Jesus saith unto him, Thomas, because thou hast seen me, thou hast believed: blessed are they that have not seen, and yet have believed”— That of the afternoon was from Luke 17.20. [“]And when he was demanded of the Pharisees when the kingdom of God should come, he answered them and said, the kingdom of God cometh not with observation: 21. Neither shall they say, lo here! or lo there! for behold, the kingdom of God is, within you.”— There is much to say upon this text which Mr Green did not say— He explained what he understood by the word observation—that is outward
