Shew, but he did not expound the terms kingdom of God—words used in the new Testament, in several different senses— A copious exposition of the words, with illustrating references to all the passages of the Gospels where they are used would belong to the subject of a discourse upon this text— The kingdom of God, is an expression, first introduced by Jesus Christ himself, and a part of the prayer which he taught his disciples is that it may come— The question of the Pharisees, probably alluded to that passage of his prayer; and the answer is equally adapted to it— The kingdom of God, will not come by the sound of a trumpet; or the shout of Victory— The kingdom of God is within you. It is the purification of the heart from evil passions— It is a life of Charity and Love— I read also two Sermon’s of Barrow upon the Love of God— I cannot discover the beauty or sublimity of this writers Style, of which I have heard much—nor account for the resuscitation of his fame in the recent critical Legislation of England— In these Sermons he undertakes to define the Love of God; and a more clumsy, loose, parenthetical, ungrammatical Sentence of English was never written— He conveys no distinct idea; and gives no shadow of a reason for the power of the Sentiment in the heart of man. The Love of God is in the Religion of Moses the first of human duties; because obedience to the Will of God embraces the whole duty of Man— Barrow confuses what was clear instead of elucidating what was obscure. But I must pause— Mr Sprague and Degrand spent the Evening here—and my brother and his Son Isaac Hull— At five this afternoon I bathed and swam at the wharf— There was a corner of a thunder shower in the Evening.
28. IV:15. Monday.

I went in to Boston this morning with John Kirke; attended at the Probate Office, and returned the Judge’s warrant for taking an Inventory of the Estate of Thomas Boylston, and also the affidavit that I had given the necessary notices of my appointment as Administrator de bonis non, with the Will annexed of his goods and Estate— An entry was made on the back of the order for taking the Inventory, that no Assets have been found within this Commonwealth— That the only property of the deceased that has come to my knowledge is a sum of about forty thousand dollars, received by Petty Vaughan at London; and that if any property of the deceased should hereafter come into my possession, I would duly account for the same— Mr Heard the Register told me that I was entitled to a copy of these papers which would be ready to be delivered to me in a fortnight— I then went to my Son Charles’s Office, and after executing sundry family commissions, at the sound of the Clock at one departed and returned to Quincy— I had received an invitation from the Charlestown Lyceum to attend at their celebration of the second centennial anniversary of the landing at that place. Edward Everett delivered the Oration, at three in the afternoon. I had also an invitation from Mr Baldwin, to his house, after the Address—but the hours did not suit my convenience, and I neglected to attend. But there is always dissipation of a day when I go to Boston— I wasted the afternoon in finishing the fourth and last Volume of the Correspondence of Madame du Deffand. Her Letters to Voltaire are far less pleasing or curious than those to Horace Walpole— Her Portraits have no features— Her Letters to Voltaire consist of unceasing complaints of ennui—the tediousness of Life—gross adulation of her correspondent, and constant teizing of him to send her his writings.
I finished also the Oration of Cicero, for Publius Sextius.— It is not among the select Orations translated either into French or English: but as a historical monument it is equal in interest, to any one of the whole collection. It is one of the longest that have been preserved; and contains a full exposition of the causes of his own exile, and of his motives for submitting to it; rather than defend himself by civil War— In the violent struggles for his recall Sextius had been one of the principal actors in his favour; and in a riot between a party of men headed by him, and the ruffian gang of Clodius, he had been wounded and left for dead in the Street— For this affair he was prosecuted, upon the Lutatian Law, against armed violence (de vi,) and was defended by Hortensius and others as well as by Cicero— His Oration is more a defence of himself than of Sextius— There is much both of invective and of ridicule cast upon the two Consuls of the year of exile, Piso and Gabinius; a very pleasant and humorous exhibition of the Epicurean Philosophy; and a very lively description of the two great political parties in Rome—the populares and the optimates— The duty of Patriotism, and of setting toil and danger at defiance for the service of the Republic, is set forth with equal ardour and beauty; and the injustice of condemning Sextius for Violence, in a fray from which he had barely escaped with Life is shewn with irresistible force— Evening party at T. Greenleaf’s.
29. IV:20. Tuesday.

The day passed without interruption of visitors; but was eroded by trivial household concerns, always annoying to me, because I have passed my life in ignorance of them. The important business of this morning was to refine with the yolk’s and shells of a dozen eggs, a pipe of Madeira Wine— I visited my garden—in which nothing draws my attention, but the results of my experiments to raise trees from the seed, nut and stone. In the Summer house-cellar there are Seven Oaks; all by the leaf apparently Chesnut white Oaks— The Acorns were planted about the 1st. of October 1826— They came up in May 1827. and this is the fourth year of their growth. The stems are slender; the leaves very large— The height of the tallest, before this years growthinches— The same tree has since I arrived here put out a shootinches long, but it is attacked by large Ants, which have eaten up most of its leaves as they were unfolding; and one of which I found working at the joint from which it sprouted to cut it off— The single Hickory Walnut tree, of which I planted the nut in October 1804. bears fruit again this year. The nuts were first perceptible some days after I came, and are now rapidly growing in size— There are in the garden below sixteen apple-trees from seeds which I planted last Summer, two of which may possibly live. I now regret that I did not sow and plant more last year— After dinner, I slept an hour, began to read Voltaire’s Commentary upon Corneille— Bathed and swam at the wharf, and found the day gone; and nothing done— In the Morning I had read the Oration against Vatinius, which consists of a Series of interrogatories— A furious invective in the form of Questions. Vatinius had been produced as a witness against Sextius; and had testified against him— Ciceros object was to discredit his testimony, and he charges him in the most unqualified manner with lying—tells him that no man thinks him fit to live and that he would have passed over in silence his testimony as too contemptible for notice, had he not thought it best to break down his impudence, and entangle him in the net of his own inconsistencies, by putting to him a few questions— Vatinius had been a tribune of the People when Caesar was Consul; and had been one of his devoted instruments— He now endeavoured to sustain himself by alledging the
authority of Caesar, and the weight of this allegation in the address with which Cicero encounters and evades it— One of the heaviest charges against Vatinius, is that he appeared dressed in black—cum toga pulla, at a public banquet given by Quintus Arrius— The contrast of the black and the white garment—atratus et albatus is here strongly marked, and shews how among the Romans, Sentiment was connected with manners— This Vatinius and the Consul Gabinius were the men with whom Cicero afterwards at the instance of Pompey and under the fear of the first triumvirate became reconciled—and for which he apologises in the Letter to Lentulus 1.9.
30. IV:15. Wednesday.

A Mr Blake, called this morning an Assistant of the Marshal of the District in taking the census; and took down the number of persons in the family with their respective ages; I set down here below the names—13 persons. Mr Tufts and his daughter Susan paid us a morning visit— He asked me for the papers from my father and mother which he had put into my hands last year and which I thought he had intended to give me— I promised to look them up and return them— Mrs Boylston brought from Mr Curtis a duplicate of my Letter to Thomas and John Baring, and Joshua Bates, as Administrator de Bonis Non of Thomas Boylston, with the Will annexed, which I signed and she took it back. She shewed me also a Note of Moses Gill to her dated last January on interest for 984 dollars 76 Cents, which I advised her to keep till something shall if ever be received from Petty Vaughan— General Sumner and Mr Dodge heretofore Consul at Marseilles were here— Sumner spoke much of the horticultural Society, and of the prospect of improvement in the Summer fruits, to be expected from them: also of the insects which destroy the fruit trees—and said the Secretary of the Society thought he had discovered the worm which is ravaging the Pear trees— Dodge complained of his having been removed from his Office of Consul at Marseilles—thought it a peculiar hardship, because he had given up his business as a merchant to attend altogether to his consular official duties— But the severest part of his misfortune he seemed to think was his having received information of his removal upon his birth-day. Sumner reminded him of a man whom the reprobate James Lovell advised to go over to Dr Morse at Charlestown, and be born again— I bathed and swam at the Creek this afternoon, and then called and spent an hour at Mr Daniel Greenleaf who is yet lame, from his accident at New-Bedford— After I came home my brother and Edward Miller were here— I began the Oration of Cicero for Balbus, and read some of the Preliminary remarks of Voltaire to his Commentary upon Corneille.

Day— I rise usually between four and five almost always before the Sun, now just commencing his return from his Northern Declination— Read three Chapters of the New Testament, and then 15 Sections of an Oration of Cicero— This brings me to breakfast time between seven and eight— I then waste the hours in busy trifling till 2 when we dine— After dinner a nap of two hours— A ride, a walk, a bath and idle reading in my library till dusk— Then with my family till ten, and to bed— Shall I never do better?
